text: for decades Washington's policy towards
Cuba was based on two things the carrot
and the stick the stick is the US
economic embargo which can only be
lifted by Congress the carrot however
was too tantalizing wet foot dry foot
policy a measure which granted Cubans
who made it on the US soil the right to
stay without a visa tens of thousands of
Cubans made the journey every year with
many risking their lives in the Florida
Straits in inflatable rafts or
unseaworthy vessels since was introduced
in 1995 the Cuban government has blamed
the measure for the brain drain on the
island so when President Obama
reinstated diplomatic ties with Cuba and
visited the country last year we can
safely say the Castro government will
have urged him in no uncertain terms to
lift the policy despite the temptation
of the free entry to the United States
the decision to remove it was broadly
welcomed by some in Havana hold up I
don't wanna okay on the one hand it is
good because we as Cubans we are more
certain that we cannot go through this
route and there won't be as much loss of
human life and also much blood spilling
in the sea for every boat that goes
there there are thousands and thousands
of Cubans who take crazy blind risks
without knowing if we can survive or not
having that I won't drive it was hurting
our young people especially among the
majority of people who attempted the
journey there was a large percentage of
failure and loss of life on the way for
their part the Cuban authorities echoed
the statement from the White House and
applauded the move particularly a
decision to lift a policy which
encouraged Cuba's doctors and nurses to
abandon the country on what we see in
this joint declaration is an important
step for Cuba's national interest but
also for the national interest of the US
that said I think this question of
whether the Trump administration will
support the new Accord must be answered
by the new government of the United
States
perhaps the key line about this change
is revealed in the statement from the
White House by taking this step we are
treating Cuban migrants the same way we
treat migrants from other countries
now that's something that the government
of RAL Castro who's been calling for for
decades but undoubtedly there are Cubans
out there who would have been hoping to
use the wet foot dry foot policy one day
and who on hearing this news had their
hopes dashed for a future in the United
States will grant BBC News Havana
